awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Taking the long view: Investigating the role of biology interest and far-sighted career goals on students' persistence in STEM career pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
Many efforts are underway to meet the science and technology workforce needs in the United States. Although students enter college with interests in STEM fields, many do not persist in these majors.  This project will investigate two fundamental, yet understudied factors that may limit participation of students, including those from underrepresented groups in biology careers: the strength of students' interest in the discipline they are pursuing and the clarity of their career goals throughout their studies. This proposal lays the groundwork for investigating the influence of these two factors on post-college preparedness by documenting the current range of interest and career goals in entering undergraduate biology majors at two institutions and investigating whether these factors predict the critical experiences students pursue during their undergraduate career. Students without clear career goals and interests may not recognize which experiences are important to pursue during their undergraduate career, may have trouble choosing among different beneficial experiences, or may not be motivated to persist when things get difficult. This project will also advance our understanding about how early students need to develop these goals and interests to become competitive during college. These findings will inform the design and deployment of effective interventions to help students develop career goals and stronger disciplinary interests before they lose opportunities to access critical experiences. 

The intellectual merit of this project is to bring interest development theory and, for the first time, vocational development theory to characterize the roles of biology interest and career goal clarity in advancing students' progress in biology career paths. Retrospective interviews with medical and graduate students in biology will characterize the timing of and relationships between students' interest and career goal development and their pursuit of critical disciplinary experiences during their undergraduate career. A longitudinal study of a large sample of entering biology majors with different levels of biology interest and at different stages of career goal development will complement this analysis by tracking when students acquire critical disciplinary experiences over the first three years of college. Together, these studies will provide evidence on 1) how early and how often students who matriculate to medical and graduate school access critical experiences, 2) whether disciplinary interest and career goal development impact pursuit of critical experiences and maintenance of biology career goals, and 3) whether students from historically underserved groups are less likely to enter college with developed biology interests and/or career goals. In addition, the project will increase understanding the importance of biology career pathways as an alternative to the traditional measure of persistence: retention in the biology major.

por.por_cntn:
Ten years ago, the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology published a report titled Engage to Excel: Producing one million additional college graduates with degrees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). This report describes the need for more graduates pursing STEM careers and the challenges faced by the US in retaining these students, especially students from minoritized groups. It is critical to understand the factors that contribute to student persistence in STEM, and according to extensive qualitative research published in Talking About Leaving Revisited by Thiry and colleagues, lack of interest and misalignment of career goals with learning experiences often lead to departure from STEM majors.

The goals of this project were to understand interest and career goal development among biology undergraduates and characterize how these factors influence students' pursuit of and access to critical extracurricular experiences that are beneficial in accessing advanced degrees. Two branches of the project were established: a) a qualitative branch, concerned with understanding how biology interest is conceptualized and the role of interest and career goals in prompting pursuit of critical experiences, and b) a quantitative branch, concerned with understanding how students' background factors (e.g., race/ethnicity, socioeconomic status) influence their interest and career goals and whether the intensity of interest or specificity of career goals can predict engagement in critical experiences. This outcomes report addresses the quantitative branch; the report for award #1712160 addressed the qualitative branch.

The first key contribution entailed work to develop, refine, and test the validity of a new instrument to assess undergraduates interest in biology (doi.org/10.1186/s40594-020-00217-4). This project was co-led with the qualitative branch researchers. In this work, we proposed that a developmental framework is appropriate for understanding interest in biology since it would allow researchers to investigate how higher levels of interest lead to persistence in STEM. Using a common suite of instrument development practices, we wrote survey items, confirmed that they were interpreted as intended, and used psychometric statistics to investigate the structure of our new measure. This work resulted in a measure of student interest that assessed students' feelings about biology, perceived value of biology, and reengagement with biology content. Combined, these dimensions measure biology interest as described according to the four-phase model of interest development proposed by Hidi and Renninger.

A second key contribution was developing a statistical primer that described how researchers can establish an existing survey instrument is working the way it is expected to with their study population (doi.org/10.1187/cbe.18-04-0064).  This primer describes how to employ a statistical approach, factor analysis, to assess a survey, orients researchers to the output of this approach and to current thinking in statistics about determining the fit of the survey to the data. This paper has been cited 117 times as of November 2022.

A third key contribution is the collection of two large longitudinal datasets that will allow researchers to assess the role of interest and career goals on persistence in STEM career pathways. Specifically, a data set of 1,143 undergraduates will allows researchers to answer the question how does interest in biology content and career goal at the start of college predict student retention in a biology majors three years later above and beyond student background factors.  A longitudinal dataset of 209 students documents how interest in biology content and career goals change over the course of a student’s first three years of college and the extracurricular experiences they engage in each semester to become competitive for their next steps in their STEM career pathways. With this dataset researchers can characterize how interest and career goals influence when student engage in critical experiences and how many they pursue.  Collectively this research will inform the development of interventions to help students leverage their biology interests and career goals to access critical experiences.
